column2: Apple scab is a serious disease of apples and ornamental crabapples caused by Venturia inaequalis that attacks both leaves and fruit. The fungal disease forms pale yellow or olive-green spots on the upper surface of leaves.

Black rot is a disease of apples that infects fruit  leaves and bark caused by the fungus Botryosphaeria obtusa. It can also jump to healthy tissue on pear or quince trees. It can be controlled by general purpose fungicide like copper-based sprays and lime sulfur.
column3: Sulfur Plant Fungicide can be used in pre-blossom applications and must go on before rainy or spore discharge periods. Apply 2 Tbsp/ gallon of water and treat as a soil drench (2 Tbsp/ gallon of water ) or foliar spray (3-4 tsp/ gallon of water) to prevent and attack fungal problems up to the day of harvest.
column4: but is typically a secondary fungus of weak or dead tissues in other plants.

column2: Cedar apple rust is a fungal disease caused by Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae that requires juniper plants to complete its complicated two year life-cycle. Spores overwinter as a reddish-brown gall on young twigs of various juniper species.
Powdery mildew of sweet and sour cherry is caused by Podosphaera clandestina
column3: an obligate biotrophic fungus. Mid- and late-season sweet cherry (Prunus avium) cultivars are commonly affected
column4: rendering them unmarketable due to the covering of white fungal growth on the cherry surface.

column2: Grey leaf spot (GLS) is a foliar fungal disease that affects corn. GLS is considered one of the most significant yield-limiting diseases of corn worldwide. There are two fungal pathogens that cause GLS: Cercospora zeae-maydis and Cercospora zeina.
